Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Transportable Energy Storage for Enhancing Power Grid Resiliency to Natural Disasters

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is motivated by the society-scale urgency of reducing the impact of natural disasters on power grids in the light of increasing frequency and damage of hurricane strikes in the US Atlantic and Gulf Coast region. One way to enhance the ability of power grid operators to withstand such disasters is to ensure availability of backup flexibility resources that can be timely deployed prior to the disaster. This flexibility can then be used to prevent critical equipment failures during the disaster and to accelerate post-disaster grid restoration.

This project will develop and validate the concept of mobile energy storage (ES) units that can provide backup flexibility to power grids. Provided a timely disaster scenario, these units can be moved using public transportation routes from their stationary locations to the locations, where they can enhance power grid resiliency. This objective requires addressing two immediate research gaps. First, there is no decision-making strategy that can optimally route, reconfigure and control mobile ES units as needed to reduce the impact of the anticipated disaster. Second, existing ES technologies makes it difficult to reconfigure ES units on a short notice. Using the real-life predictions and ex-post data from Hurricane Harvey, this project will design a data-driven approach to enable the optimal routing, reconfigure and control of mobile ES units to enhance power grid resiliency. The proposed approach will be accompanied by the development of a new electrochemical ES mechanism that is capable of generating two transportable energy carriers: redox-active species (such as those used on redox flow batteries) and hydrogen (e.g. available in refineries along the US Gulf Coast). Methodologically, this project will advance techniques for solving multi-stage optimization problems with binary recourse decisions and grid-scale energy storage mechanisms based on electrochemical water splitting reactions with solution-based redox couples as intermediates for water electrolysis.

The project will enhance the tool set and knowledge to mitigate the impact of natural disasters and will be made available to educate power grid utilities just in time for the following Atlantic Hurricane Season (2018). The PIs will aim to engage underrepresented groups in STEM research activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As planned in the proposal, the project yielded the following major intellectual outcomes:

  • We developed and tested, via computer-aided simulations, the concept of mobile energy storage units and demonstrated that it can significantly improve power grid resiliency in case of natural disasters.  This work has been reported in the following publications led by PI Dvorkin and/or Ph.D. student Kim:

1. J. Kim and Y. Dvorkin, "Enhancing Distribution System Resilience with Mobile Energy Storage and Microgrids," IEEE Transactions on Smart Grids, pp. 1-10, early access, 2018.

2. S. Mehrdad, S. Mousavian, G. Madraki, Y. Dvorkin, "Cyber-Physical Resilience of Electrical Power Systems Against Malicious Attacks: A Review," Springer: Current Sustainable/Renewable Energy Reports, pp. 1-.9, Jan. 2018.

3. J. Kim and Y. Dvorkin, "Enhancing Distribution Resilience with Mobile Energy Storage: A Progressive Hedging Approach," IEEE Power and Energy Society General Meeting, Portland, Oregon, pp. 1-5, August 2018

These publications validated the ability of mobile ES units to move between different locations to tradeoff the least-cost operations during normal operations and the need to enhance power grid resilience in case of natural disasters. Numerical experiments in [1] demonstrate that energy storage mobility can reduce load shedding caused by natural disasters up to 10.52% in an experimental set-up, which is realistically "close" to a suburban- and urban-area outbreaks of Hurricane Harvey. We also identified that the ability to improve power resiliency depends on the capital cost and cycling efficiency of mobile energy storage untis. The key methodological novelty reported in [1,3] is an extension of the Progressive Hedging algorithm to deal with mixed-integer recourse decisions, while solving multi-stage, stochastic mixed integer programs.

  • We designed, prototyped, and tested a new electrochemical technology that supports the mobile energy storage operations and is capable of providing back up support for electric power grids in case of natural disasters.  This work has been carried out in collaboration between co-PIs Dvorkin and Modestino, and their Ph.D. students. The main methodological The results have been demonstrated in a laboratory environment (an actual kW-scale energy storage element was designed) and integrated into power grid simulations in a "hardware-in-the-loop" manner. These results are not yet released for publication, but the team submitted one provisional patent application (MOD01-02) and expects to publish this work within a year since the project completion.

Taken together, these project outcomes are well co-aligned with the anticipated results of the proposal. Additionally, the co-PIs took forward multiple steps to disseminate their results:

  • Implementations of models and algorithms (with some test data sets)developed in the project are made available for public access via PI Dvorkin's web-page: 

https://wp.nyu.edu/dvorkin/code-data/

  • Conference presentations:
    • "Transportable Energy Storage for Enhancing Power Grid Resiliency to Natural Disasters," NSF's 43rd Annual Natural Hazards Workshop, Denver, Colorado, July 2018.
    • "Enhancing Distribution Resilience with Mobile Energy Storage: A Progressive Hedging Approach," IEEE Power and Energy Society General Meeting, Portland, Oregon, August 2018
    • "Enhancing Distribution Resilience with Mobile Energy Storage," INFORMS Annual Meeting, Phoenix, Arizona, October 2018.  (invited regular talk)
    • "Enhancing Cyber-Physical Resilience of Power Grids," IEEE Power and Energy Society General Meeting, Atlanta, Georgia, to be held in August 2019 (invited panel talk)

 

  •  Additionally, as per the proposal, the project team pursued broader impacts that included:
    • Participation in NYU's Applied Research Innovations in Science and Engineering program for high-school students (co-PIs hosted 2 students each; in PI Dvorkin's group both students were female from underrepresented racial groups)
    • Outreach to industry: PI Dvorkin has lead the effort to apply the outcomes of this research in practice by reaching out to NYSERDA, Consolidated Edison of New York and New York State Smart Grid Consortium. This project facilitated the PI's Dvorkin ability to assist New York State Smart Grid Consortium in assessing one of their project aimed at re-engineering Puerto Rico's power system.
